comment: Here’s an outline of this video: 0:37: A quick overview / refresher of arrays 2:49: What is memory? 6:46: Examining memory and storage on my laptop 7:48: How integers are stored on memory 9:51: A simple model of memory (a long tape of bytes) 13:55: Storing an array of integers instead of single integers  Also, find this entire series in a playlist here: https://goo.gl/wy3CWF

Thanks! Great explanation!  I have got a few questions: 1. If we store integers in a consecutive bytes in memory, and we do the same for arrays of integers, then how does memory understand that it is an array and not just separate integers? 2. - I have the same question for how memory is split between applications. Let’s say I have Pycharm running, and then I start Chrome and Slack, they have got their space in memory. But what happens when I use all the space for PyCharm and it reached the start of Chrome's memory.. If I need more space for PyCharm, how and where it will be allocated? I can see in the Activity Monitor app on mac, that memory for Chrome is split into different items. Does it mean that if we run out of memory for a specific application, it will try to allocate new space somewhere else in the memory?

Key Points: - It's very unusual to have mixed variable types in an array - You can't just add more partitions at the end of an array After already allocating memory for a list, you don't know what'll be allocated after that and to store an array you need consecutive bytes.  To add more you need to dynamically create a new, longer array and copy over those values to it again.

One correction to your explanation: If you have a variable that being defined as int8 for example, it will be stored in the memory using a single byte. Then the conversion from 8 bits to 32 bits (for a 32-bit processor) should be done before any processing on that variable. (So saving some memory, but it may slightly increase processing time because of the additional step of converting the int8 to int32)

Task manager on windows

Fun fact: If you're wondering how hibernate works on Windows, your PC takes all of the data from your memory and writes it onto a folder in your storage/hard drive before your computer powers off. When it powers back on, the data from that folder is written back onto your memory, and it appears as if your computer was never off in the first place!

In case anyone's wondering how to examine the memory and storage on Windows: To see your memory, right click on the start icon and click on system. Your memory should be under Device Specifications. To see your storage, open file explorer, click on This PC, and your storage should be listed under Local Disk (C:). You can right click on Local Disk (C:) and select properties for more information. To see how much memory, your applications are using, open the Task Manager application and it'll show memory usage, cpu usage, among other things under the Processes tab.

Atharv Khatri  Firefox is quite good about only using memory for active tabs.   You can also go to Preferences -> General -> Performance -> Content process limit and reduce this number to greatly reduce the memory consumption. I have 8gb RAM and am happy with Content process limit set to 2. You could set it to 1 to use even less RAM.   You might find pages load more slowly if you are opening multiple pages though. But if you're like me and like having several tabs open for long periods but don't want firefox to use all of your RAM and CPU cores, this is the way to do that :D

OK, I am starting a longer note on this video. Please note that despite the critical remarks below, I gave a you thumbs up because your content is useful.   1. You used the same boxes to represent bits and then bytes - it would be nice if you used a different drawing to avoid confusion. https://youtu.be/pmN9ExDf3yQ?list=PLBZBJbE_rGRV8D7XZ08LK6z-4zPoWzu5H&t=803   2. The explanation of why arrays cannot be easily extended was way too long. You digressed to explain the difference between RAM and Disk storage, and then to explain about storage for different types (which by the way is hardware platform and/or language specific), and then finally you got back to arrays and consecutive bytes.   Here is a quick one: You cannot resize arrays easily because you always need consecutive bytes and you never know what is stored past the end of your current array. This explanation took less than 30 seconds. If you were to add your visualizations, you can demonstrate that with you box analogy by showing that a bigger box with more cubbyholes will not fit on in the same original slot because there are other boxes or individual cubbyholes right behind it.
You have both RAM and Disk because RAM is way more expensive than Disk, and not because one of them is slower than the other.

Well from what I got from this video is that each array when it is instantiated, is allocated a specific space in memory of continuous bytes. After the array is made and it's already in the memory, it's unclear to the computer if there will be empty bytes after the array's position(like another int or String after the array) and because of that and that the bytes of the array need to be continuous, you can't just allocate more space in memory to add more data in an array. So the only solution to this is to make another array that can hold more data, add the data from the original one to the new one, and then from there add the extra data you want to put into the new array.

It is because whenever you are using an array it is actually a pointer to a space in memory. The index does pointer arithmetic(essentially adds to the base memory address) so if you wanted to go to the first element in the array it would be at the base address + 0 since it is already at the first location. However, if you wanted to access the second element in the array it would be located at the base memory address + 1 (in hexadecimal in the background) since the array allocates memory right next to each other. This is how I learned this in c++, and I am sure it is similar if not identical in most other high level languages.

It would be useful to explain to your viewers that nowadays most of the times an integer is 64 bit, unless specified otherwise by the programmer, this happens because most commodity hardware sold nowadays uses processors with a x86-64 bit instruction set, which has a 64 bit general purpose registers so push and pop from stack are 8 byte wide ( pointers are also 8 byte wide ), most system programming languages tend to reflect this characteristic to their user, even higher level programming languages do.

My biggest question after watching this is:   what happens when you delete older arrays (or anything stored in previous pieces of memory)? For example, if you had an array of length 4, then made a new one and deleted that older array; you would have a 4-byte gap in memory. How does the OS handle these gaps so it's not just wasted space? Because obviously you can only put another 4-byte piece of data in that slot and the more you delete older data, the more gaps you'll have, increasing potentially wasted memory.  Hopefully that made sense...and I apologize if this is a bit too complex for the scope of what you're teaching lol

This is a good question. Basically the issue you describe is memory fragmentation. Chunks of free memory surrounded by chunks of used memory.   I believe the C programming language uses a system of binned free lists to solve this problem. So in your example if you deleted a 4-byte array, that memory would be freed up and the address to the start location of that memory would be stored in a list of other addresses that also have 4-bytes of space free. Similarly, if you deleted a bigger array -- let's say of size 256 bytes -- the address of that memory would be stored in a list of of other memory locations with at least 256 bytes free. Now when you're trying to allocate a new object, the OS can behind the scenes select an appropriate location from one of your freed memory lists and thus help the memory not have as much wasted space.   It is worth noting that the size of lists will usually be rounded to a common magnitude. So if you were trying to delete an array of size 273 bytes, that would probably fall into the same bin of free memory locations as the 256 byte array. Also if free memory locations are directly next to each other, they can be combined and placed into a bigger list of free memory.  To read more about this, this is a good link: http://g.oswego.edu/dl/html/malloc.html  Also worth noting that in languages like Python handle a lot of this automatically. If you are interested in learning more about how memory allocation and deallocation is handled automatically look into reference counting and garbage collection.  Hope this helps, Keith

Hey fam, I hope that you and your loved ones are well. I would like to ask you the most important question ever asked:    Who is  Jesus? Not who is He to you. Rather, who is He really?  Jesus is the Son of God, who came to the world as a man. He lived a perfect and sinless life . Even though He was perfect and sinless, on the cross of Calvary God wrathfully punished Him for the sins of the world. 3 days later He rose from death. Now He is seated at the right hand of God, ruling as King over Heaven and Earth. On the judgment day He will judge you, me and every human being that has ever lived. Those who believed in Him will enter eternal joy with Him, but those who did not believe in Jesus will be sent to eternal condemnation.   So turn from your sins and believe in the Jesus, that you can be forgiven for all your sins, because of His death and resurrection. Ephesians 1:7 ”In Him, we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of His grace" Ephesians 2:8 ”For it is by grace you have been saved through faith, and this not from yourselves; it is the gift of God,”  John 11:25-26: "Jesus said to her, 'I am the resurrection and the life. The one who believes in me will live, even though they die; and whoever lives by believing in me will never die. Do you believe this?' 1 Corinthians 6:14: "And God raised the Lord and will also raise us up by his power." Romans 6:9: "We know that Christ, being raised from the dead, will never die again; death no longer has dominion over him."

I don't have a strong opinion per se, but I think it's a really convenient / promising technology.  For example, YouTube's auto-captioning is surprisingly accurate at this point. It probably uses ML. I was surprised when a ML algorithm beat the best human players in Dota 2 (could've been a different game), too.  At the same time though, I think it needs to be applied in the right context for it to be truly useful. For instance, predicting your reply to someone's message might not be that convenient since it'll never be that accurate anyway. On the other hand, the recommendation engines on platforms like YouTube, Netflix and Amazon are really useful and actually improve the user experience.
